stem: A 3-year-old child living in a home built in 1940 is admitted for sudden seizures and vomiting. Based on the documentation, complete the bowtie by selecting the most likely condition, the two actions the nurse should take, and the two parameters the nurse should monitor.

tabs.title: SBAR
tabs.content:
Situation: Acute encephalopathy and seizures in a toddler.
Background: Parents report the child has been 'irritable' and was found chewing on windowsill paint.
Assessment: Child is obtunded (GCS 10) with projectile vomiting.
Recommendation: Blood lead level and ICP stabilization.

tabs.title: Toxicology & Environmental Log
tabs.content:
TestResultInterpretation
Blood Lead Level (BLL)72 mcg/dLCritical (>45 mcg/dL requires chelation)
CT BrainBilateral cerebral edemaIncreased ICP
Hemoglobin8.2 g/dLLow (Lead-induced Anemia)
Social HistoryOld housing; Peeling paintEnvironmental source

actionOptions.text: Initiate seizure precautions and elevate head of bed

rationale.correct: The child presents with Lead-Induced Encephalopathy with Increased ICP (c2) due to a critical blood lead level of 72 mcg/dL. Chelation therapy (a1) is essential to remove lead. Seizure precautions and head-of-bed elevation (a2) are crucial for managing increased ICP. Monitoring neurological status (p1) and renal function (p2) is vital due to the risk of chelation-related nephrotoxicity.
clinicalPearls: Blood lead levels > 45 mcg/dL require treatment; > 70 mcg/dL are emergencies.
Lead disrupts neurotransmitters and causes cerebral edema.
Assess renal function before and during chelation.

questionTrap.howToOvercome: Address the physiological crisis (ICP and lead level) first.
